general: This law helps people who serve in the military become British citizens more easily. It makes sure they don't have to go through too many hoops or wait too long to become citizens, since they have already served their country. This way, they can continue to contribute to society as full-fledged citizens.

series.short: "British Citizenship for Armed Forces: Special Provisions for Military Service"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Citizenship (Armed Forces) Act 2014 allows for members of the armed forces to apply for British citizenship even if they were not in the UK at the beginning of the required residence period.
* Simplified point 2: The Secretary of State has discretion to waive the usual residency requirements for members of the armed forces applying for citizenship, taking into account the special circumstances of their service.
* Simplified point 3: The Act applies to England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and the British overseas territories.

summary:
The Citizenship (Armed Forces) Act 2014 helps military personnel become British citizens more easily. Even if they weren't living in the UK when they started their application, they can still apply for citizenship. The government can also ignore some rules if they think it's fair because of the person's military service. This law covers all parts of the UK and its territories.
In other words, this law makes it easier for members of the armed forces to become British citizens, regardless of where they were stationed or lived during their service. It gives the government the power to consider special circumstances related to military service when reviewing citizenship applications.
single:
•	The Citizenship (Armed Forces) Act 2014 allows members or former members of the armed forces to apply for British citizenship more easily.
•	The Act amends the British Nationality Act 1981 to make it easier for members of the armed forces to fulfill the requirements for naturalization as a British citizen.
•	The Act applies to England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and the British overseas territories.
•	The Act makes it easier for members of the armed forces to become British citizens, regardless of where they are stationed or if they have been stationed in the UK.
•	The Act allows the Secretary of State to waive certain requirements for naturalization if there are "special circumstances" in the individual case.
•	The Act came into force two months after it was passed.
